intro: Chrysanthemum sibiricoides, commonly known as the Siberian chrysanthemum, is a perennial flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring hairy stems and lance-shaped, gray-green leaves. Its showy yellow to orange flowers bloom in late summer to early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has been used in traditional medicine for its potential health benefits.
